text: Thank you for being here this weekend and being part of this Donna Weekend, the heart of which will take place tomorrow.
And our teachers for the weekend will be arriving tomorrow in buses from all over the county.
And I'd like to take this opportunity tonight to clarify a little bit about what Donna really is.
We translate it as giving, but giving doesn't reach it at all.

And we have that problem with the English language and translating some of these Buddhist terms into English because the English versions of them, the closest English word to them, has totally different meanings.
And as a result, they become misinterpreted.
And that's why many of them we retain in the original form, such as Donna.
Donna is one of the paramitas.
And these paramitas have been in existence a long time.
They're part of Mahayana Buddhism, which Zen is a part of.
And Donna is the first of those.
And each one of the paramitas, when you try to translate them, you somehow miss what they're about.
For example, we translate Prajna paramita.
Paramita literally means other shore or to cross over.
And our way of understanding crossing over to the other shore in Zen is that the other shore arrives, or indeed, that the other shore is right here, right now.
And wisdom, if you look it up in a dictionary, talks about accumulating knowledge.
It has nothing to do with knowledge, nor does it have anything to do with knowing.
So that the calling it wisdom misses it.
The same with the word Karuna, we translate as compassion.
Compassion has a sense of empathy about it, which implies self and other.
In compassion, there is no dualism.
There is no self or other.
And we translate dana as giving.
And that, too, misses the point.
There can be no dana, unless there is both giving and receiving occurring simultaneously.
So that the giver and the receiver are unified.
There's no doer or the thing that you're doing to.
There's no effort or even sense of it occurring.
Compassion happens the way your hair grows.
And it's not almsgiving or donation or beneficence or benevolence or benefaction.
It's not contribution or gift or philanthropy or offering.
But rather, it's the practice of total, unequivocal relinquishment.
The great master, Hui Hai, who was a successor of Basso, talked about it in a dialogue with one of his monks.
The monk asked, by what means can the gateway of our school be entered?
The master said, by means of dana paramita.
According to the Buddha and the Bodhisattva path, the monk said,
the Bodhisattva path consists of six paramitas.
Why then have you mentioned only one?
Please explain why this one alone provides a sufficient means for us to enter.
The master said, deluded people fail to understand that the other five all proceed from dana paramita
and that it's by practice, by its practice, that all others are fulfilled.
Why it's the first one of the paramitas.
Why is it called dana paramita?
Answer, relinquishment of dualism of opposites.
It means total relinquishment of ideas as to the dual nature of good and bad,
being and non-being, love and aversion, void and non-void,
concentration and distraction, pure and impure.
By giving all of them up, we attain to a state in which all opposites are seen as empty.
The real practice of dana paramita entails achieving this state without any thought of,
now I see that opposites are void, or now I have relinquished all of them.
We may also call it the simultaneous cutting off of the myriad types of current cause.
For it is when these are cut off that the whole dharma nature becomes void, empty.
And this emptiness of the dharma nature means the non-dwelling of the mind upon anything whatsoever.
Once that state is achieved, not a single form can be discerned.
Because our self-nature is non-existent and does not contain a single thing foreign to itself.
That which contains no single thing is true reality, the marvelous form of the Tathagatha.
It's said in the Diamond Sutra,
those who relinquish all forms are called Buddhas, or enlightened ones.
So basically what he's saying is that dana is about forgetting the self.
When there's no self, there's no other.
This is the diamond net of Indra, where all things are interconnected,
where all things nourish each other and themselves.
Who forget the self is body and mind fallen away.
In our practice, giving and receiving is at the heart of almost everything that we do.
That's what our service is about.
We receive the teachings and we return gratitude.
We receive food and we acknowledge.
Therefore, we eat this food with everyone.
We eat to stop all evil, to practice good.
Save all sentient beings and to accomplish the Buddha way.
So the receiving of the food, it's taken with the intent of giving, to follow it.
We receive the teachings and we give.
So giving and receiving, the heart of that in Japanese Buddhism,
they have the practice of takahatsu.
And there they try to recreate that practice of giving and receiving,
where the monk begs for food and receives food
and then gives a chance something for the person that's given them the food.
And it's in that giving and receiving that these two people are unified.
So the giving and receiving is constantly a manifestation of the interrelatedness,
codependency, mutual causality of the diamond net of Indra,
in which all things, every speck of dust in this vast universe is interrelated,
is codependent, has a mutual causality.
What happens to one thing happens to the totality of it.
That diamond net exists in the three dimensions of space
as well as the fourth dimension of time.
It's because that there's both giving and receiving happening simultaneously
When it's really happening that way, it's never exhausted.
And that's why I've always felt that it's essential to people in the helping professions
to really understand what they're doing.
If they're not receiving while they're giving,
if they're doing something for somebody else,
if they're helping somebody else or saving somebody else,
it's all going in one direction.
If they have not yet understood that they are receiving,
that there's a possibility to be received, to receive something.
Healer and the healed are both healed in the process.
And when you understand that, you don't exhaust anything.
When I think back at the teachers that I've known in my time of practice,
The real teachers have boundless energy, people say.
Well, they're plugged into the center of the universe itself.
That's where the nourishment comes from.
It's by the giving and receiving happening simultaneously.
Asatani Roshi was 88 years old or 89 years old.
Close to the end of his life.
He had to be helped by two Jesus to go to this Jukai ceremony.
The last Jukai ceremony that he did the day before he died.
And he couldn't even do his bows.
They helped him to his seat.
His voice was very weak as he introduced the whole thing.
And he offered the incense and began the ceremony.
The power of his presence enveloped the entire group of people.
He completed the Jukai ceremony as if he were 30 years old instead of 88 years old.
And then relapsed into his being very weak and helped out of the place and everything.
That Jukai ceremony was filling him with energy.
What he was giving, he was receiving.
The next day, he never got out of bed.
He asked his attendant at one point while she was preparing breakfast to sit him up in bed
so he could sit in a Zazen posture.
When she came back, she found him dead.
Where did that energy come from?
It came from the very process of dhana.
And all of what we do is dhana.
The self gives the self for the sake of giving the self.
The other gives the other for the sake of giving the other.
The karmic force of such giving prevails as far as the heavenly world and the human world.
So it's not dhana unless it's non-dual, no separation.
Dogen talks about dhana in terms of loving words,
working for the welfare of all beings,
And his words are the best way of expressing them.
Loving speech means that as you meet sentient beings,
you first arouse a sense of compassion in your mind
and treat them with considerate and affectionate words.
As you take delight in affectionate words,
and then even those loving words,
which were hitherto unknown and unperceived,
in terms of working for the welfare of all beings,
Working for the welfare of all beings
means that you contrive ways to benefit
all sentient beings, high and low.
The practice of benefiting others is the total truth.
Hence, it serves both self and other far and wide.
Therefore, serve enemies and friends equally
and assist self and other without discrimination.
you will see that this is the reason
are all naturally engaged in the activity
And your understanding will certainly serve
This applies equally to the self and to others.
There is a truth that after the self
the self lets itself be assimilated to the other.
This relationship of self and other
is infinitely varied according to the circumstances.
what dana is directing itself to,
that we call the diamond net,
Each one of us has that
We cover it by our conditioning.
We cover it by our ideas
